characters: THE CAMERA IS OUTSIDE OF THE ROOM. THE SCENE IS SHOT THRO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIDEON, a strongly built elderly black man, is sitting at table. On the table is a large bowl of fruit. A crocheted tablecloth hangs over the side of the table. Gideon is dressed in a white suit and wearing a pair of well-polish wing-tip shoes. His hat almost covers his eyes, which are points of greenish coals. The fruit in the bowl is engulf in flames. The flames look as if they are DRIPPING from the tableclo to the floor. Gideon's shoes start to SMOULDER. His shoes BURST INTO FLAMES which spread up his pants leg. His head falls forward as if he had suddenly fallen to sleep. He twiddles his thumbs very slowly in a circle. He crosses h legs as if to get comfortable. The camera moves to a CLOSE UP of his burning shoes. The image of his feet begins to appear through his shoes; the flames fade; the background changes as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon's bare feet are resting on reddish dry earth. Gide is sitting in his backyard under a fruit tree with a Bibl resting in his hands. His house is a small, neatly painted bungalow in South Central Los Angeles. Corn, tomatoes, other vegetables gro the yard. Chickens scratch around. He slowly awakens; his hands are trembling. He looks arou and sees the chickens. He looks up at the sky and sighs, some relief. SUNNY, Gideon's grandson, five years old, has been watchi him from the back window of the house. He leaves the wind

dialogues.speaker: SUNNY
dialogues.text: Sunny peeps in the workroom. Through the crack in the doo Woman waves to Sunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is nearly filled with pregnant women and their husbands. SUZIE, Gideon's wife, late 60's or early 70's, picture of health, is giving a last bit of instruction be the class ends. Some of the people are already preparing leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, especially you men, that working together now will already have formed a bond before the child arrives. The woman is very sensitive. Somewhere in the room a Male Voice booms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. There is a bit of LAUGHTER as all start putting away thei things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon looks over at the chickens, scratching around in t garden. He calls to them, but they don't respond. He puts shoes on and walks towards the back door of the house. Entering the house, he stops and waits inside the door peeping out. In a sort of devilish manner he talks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoiling the little foxes that spoil my vines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of the backyard. Nothing. Suddenly, with the grace a suspicion of alley cats, kids jump over Gideon's back fen look around timidly, and start climbing up his fruit tree Gideon walks down the steps slowly while humming in a dee voice. He turns the water on and walks over to the tree, trapping the kids. Dangling legs, hanging from the tree, to scurry up the tree to safety. Gideon sprays the tree w water. Wet kids fall out of the tree and in one motion le the fence. Gideon cuts the water off and slaps the dirt o his hands. He is quite pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the wet kids is watching Gideon as he goes back in the house. The boy signals the others who slowly follow i single file. They jump the fence and climb back up the tr They let their half-eaten fruit fall to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie opens a letter and a picture of a baby falls out. S looks at the picture before reading the letter. She tries to find a place for it among the other baby pictures that cover the entire mirror on the dresser. Gid comes in and starts to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mind plays tricks on me. Is it okay if I take a bath now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is gone. Rhonda is in the bathroom. RHONDA, Gideon's granddaughter, 13 years old, comes out o the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking through my trunk and I can't find my toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a charm that my great grandmother made me. Everyone notices the worried look on Gideon's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my daddy calls, tell him I walked home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be careful and thank you for looking after Sunny. Sunny is asleep on the sofa with a half-eaten apple ready fall out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother and his wife are taking advantage of a situation. I hate to be mean to people but picking Sunny up when they feel like it has to come to an end. Now I'm going to ask him how come he couldn't be at your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother the poor boy. It just takes some people a little longer to figure out who they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how two brothers can be so different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP BAKER, who is thirteen, crawls out of his pigeon cag holding two birds that he throws up in the air. He climbs upon the garage roof and throws rocks at the birds to kee them flying. He WHISTLES and YELLS at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the birds circle Skip's house, they do backward rolls death grips. Skip throws more rocks to keep them flying. rocks land on Gideon's roof. The SOUND of a person trying to learn how to play a TRUMP breaks the pleasant SOUNDS of the pigeons popping their w and flying in circles over the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODNEY BAKER is about nine. He stands next to a shaded window, trying to finger the right valves on his trumpet. tries to hit a high note, but only succeeds in making an awful screeching sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of kids walking by Rodney's window shout insultin things about his horn playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Go help your mama wash dishes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is standing over an egg that just fell on the floor The SCREECHING SOUND of the trumpet from next door is interrupted by the doorbell. Suzie cannot decide on what do, to clean the egg up or answer the door. The doorbell keeps RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two uniformed Police Officers stand impatiently at the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie invites OFFICER SCOTT and OFFICER DAVIS in. Both me are white and are in their mid-twenties. Officer Davis do most of the questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a complaint from one of your neighbors about a rooster crowing in the mornings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is shaving with a straight razor and humming to himself, obviously in a good mood. Suzie sticks her head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police are here to talk to you about the chickens. The good mood that Gideon was in dissolves quickly. Gideo wipes the soap off his face and throws the towel down. Su leaves. Gideon brushes his hair and adjusts his bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon comes in, still adjusting his bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Officer? Suzie returns to the kitchen to clean the egg on the floo Officer Scott keeps her in view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it is against the city ordinance to keep chickens or live stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always had chickens, ducks and whatnots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore, not in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We grow most of our own food. The money I get from social security, my pension and my wife's work, keeps us living on the edge. What choice do people like us have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you just have to move further out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now how far would further out be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here to argue, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys don't make anything illegal, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have a distillery pumping out barrels of moonshine. Suzie looks at Scott for a moment and goes into the kitch Gideon is about to lose control. Davis heads off the confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, just get rid of the chickens and you all have a nice day. Gideon stands in the doorway watching the Police go down steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be damned if I get rid of my chickens. I ought to get some hogs and put them out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is soft knocking on the door. Suzie enter frame wea a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother. Suzie opens the door. BABE BROTHER, Gideon's youngest son about 31, handsome, wearing an expensive suit, comes in, beating the cold off of him and blowing in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you came to the door instead of him. It gets cold at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't make any sense; you are going to drag that poor boy out in the cold air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will be alright. The camera follows Babe Brother. He passes Gideon's room where Gideon is asleep, snoring loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie and Babe Brother enter the bedroom where Sunny is sleeping. Suzie gives Babe Brother a blanket to wrap Sunn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking care of him. I will try not to be so long next time. Babe Brother gives his mother a good-night kiss. Gideon c to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? Do you think you can just treat us like your slave? It's after one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to call to let you know I was going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us settle this tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Don't try to get ahead by riding our backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) I pay my own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when? He reaches for Babe Brother but Suzie comes between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take Sunny home, please. She pushes Babe Brother away. Babe Brother walks away, staring back at his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is lying in bed. Suzie gets in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your feet are cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you to wake me when Babe Brother comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all act like two roosters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to let him get away with murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Babe Brother are so much alike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't nothing like me. How come a man has to have sons that are day and night apart? You ought to stop protecting him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always taking his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to make him a man but you keep babying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to find yourself on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom is tastefully furnished with modern art and paintings by Barns. Babe Brother wakes up with Sunny standing in the doorway looking at him. It takes Babe Brother some time to fully up. Finally he sits reluctantly on the side of the bed and Su comes over and sits next to him, trying to get his weary father interested in his remote-control racing car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to be the richest man in the world so I can be the richest father in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be rich. I want to work on the railroad like grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, if you are going to have a family, you can't always choose a job just because you like it.  (beat) I don't want you to shine anybody's shoes or be a porter. You let somebody else carry your bags. Sunny quietly gets up and follows his car out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother, having showered but still wearing his pajam drags himself to the kitchen table where his wife LINDA h huge coffee mug with the inscription, "I'm the boss", wai for him. Linda is about thirty years old and materially oriented l her husband. She is wearing a conservatively cut business dress. Sunny stops playing with his car and gets himself an empt cup. Babe Brother is about to pour him some of his coffee when Linda objects.

dialogues.speaker: NO.
dialogues.text: Sunny pleads with her in silence but Linda refuses to yie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't want any if you didn't try to keep it away from him. Linda leaves the table but stops for a moment and looks d at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you were spoiled, don't try to spoil Sunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy never gave me anything without my having to sweat for it. Every summer, the way they kept me and Junior out of trouble was to send us to Big Daddy's farm. We would get up with the chickens. Every summer the fence had to be repaired. The barn needed a coat of paint. We had to pip all of Big Mama's hundred laying hens and go to church all day on Sunday. For Big Daddy, calluses and sweat were the mark of a man. Sunny will never have to bust his knuckles like we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want Sunny to have an advantage that you and I never had, but he needs discipline, and you are not helping when I tell him to do something and you allow him to get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is a sip of coffee going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee is bad for anybody, especially for a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see you crying about my drinking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUND.
dialogues.text: Gideon is raking out the chicken coop. He puts the rake d and walks over to the garden and watches Suzie plant seed for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of standing here doing nothing, I better give those chickens some scratch before they start cackling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD JOHN is pushing his cart up the alley. Old John's fac washed so clean that it shines. His pants are dirty and h cart is full of odds and ends of no value. He looks to be about seventy and fit. Old John throws a sack on Gideon's fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie,is bent over a plant that she is tying to a stick. looks up and sees the sack on the fence. A smile appears her face. She goes over to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old John is about to take up his journey when Suzie stick her head over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolerably well. I brought you some more rabbit manure for your roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so considerate of you. Gideon sticks his head over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, look who is taking up all the sunshine. Brother John, how are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still here. Suzie leaves the two men talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something. How do you get energy to stay on the move all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't sit on your rump under my daddy's roof. No sir. If you couldn't outwork his mule, you wasn't worth the salt you put in greens. You had to wake up looking for something to do. I was raised as a mule and now I'm a rolling stone. Suzie sticks her head over the fence and hands a bag of r tomatoes to Old John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean for you to pay me for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you didn't but you have been so thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when your sunflowers come up, I'll pay you for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I planted a row just for you and you don't owe me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: off in the distance, a man is cutting his lawn. Gideon an Suzie are working in their garden. Other couples working their gardens. Two young men are working on their car, wh is creating a lot of smoke. A group of girls are sitting porch trying to sing while one of the smaller ones is try to learn a step. Skip is on the roof with his radio listening to rap music while his birds circle over head. From time to time he th a rock at them.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARTLY OPEN DOOR.
dialogues.text: It is hard to see the woman giving birth. There are peopl blocking the view of the camera. Suzie is facing the came and the woman has her back to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push too fast! Breathe! The hard part is over. You can see the top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts. The pain.  (scream) It's tearing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, give her a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do your part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell what it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I wanted a girl. Suddenly the baby begins to SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sack appears on Gideon's fence. The sound of Old John's cart is heard rattling off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Gideon, JUNIOR (Gideon's elder son, 35 years old a dark skinned), PAT (Junior's wife, who is expecting, abou 32) and Rhonda are all seated next to one another in the row. The PREACHER is knee-deep in water. He is baptizing group of young people. The members of the church are sing "Take Me To The Water". An Elderly Man who can hardly wal without help is being led down to the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Gideon, Junior, Pat and Rhonda are all seated at t table eating. Babe Brother is standing up. He looks in th pot but doesn't find it to his liking. Junior is irritate his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you going to find time to help me fix the roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all don't believe me when I tell you I'm afraid of heights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used that excuse to get out of the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always got something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother asked me not to mention it but your mother's birthday was last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadn't forgotten. I ordered some cloth but it didn't come in and I felt so bad if I would have come to her birthday without that, I just stayed at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did your wife get her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the same thing. Junior laughs at Babe Brother's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, go tell your wife to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother's car, a new Audi, is parked out front. Linda is in the front seat reading a magazine while Sunny asleep in the back seat. Babe Brother sticks his head in window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come in for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to finish reading this. What would I talk about? I haven't read this month's almanac. I don't care to hear about how the corn was this fall or how to get rid of gophers by putting garlic in their holes. They pride themselves in making life hard and that's not my cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Gideon, Junior, Pat and Rhonda are still at the ta eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Babe Brother's wife just dumps greens in the pot without washing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is a poor boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all should have been hard on him like you were me and he wouldn't be the way he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody got the same. I breast fed him like I breast fed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior, you are wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a minute. A dirt rock HITS the front windshield. Linda lets out a little scream. Babe Brother looks around. Skip is on top the roof next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to hit your car. I was throwing at my birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is looking at the price of laying mash. He digs hi hand into a barrel of scratch. Sunny also digs his hand i the barrel. Suzie is looking at new young plants. She gives the vegetables a thorough going-over. Gideon is standing in line waiting to place his order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need about five pounds of laying mash and you better give me about the same of scratch. While at the counter, Gideon turns and looks around at th prices of different items. Suzie brings her plants and pu them on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you going to have a sale on weed killer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed it. We had a two-day sale last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a sale is a two-day sale? I thought sales last a week or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day we have something different. Today's sale is hay. 25% off. If you have a horse or cow, you're in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunny looks at the Little Girl in the next car; she has h mouth pressed against the window. She is missing a tooth. Gideon is behind the wheel while Suzie holds her new plan up to the sun, carefully looking at them. Sunny, seated in the back, pokes a hole in the sack of fe The mash trickles to the floor as if from an hour glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is sitting in front of a table full of jars. Each j has a shoot and is half-filled with water. Gideon is on h knees trying to fix the hinge to a cabinet. Sunny is sitt almost under him listening to him tell stories. Sunny has coffee can full of marbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the preachers were down in the basement of the church confessing their sins to one another. They were way down in the basement 'cause they figured no one would hear them. One of the preachers said, it makes me feel too shame to tell how bad I have been. You know them young gals that sit up in the first row. I can look at them and forget my text. I'm just lost when it comes to women, even them middle age sisters. Then another preacher said, I don't think I can tell you what my sin is 'cause it's bad. Another preacher said, Brother, we all amongst friends. Tell us what's troubling your soul. Clear your conscience. Gideon takes a sip of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the preacher said, we all got a bond 'cause we confessed to one another. So let me tell you, my sin is corn liquor. I just acts a fool behind that spirit water. I loves it more than preaching. Now ain't that a sin, lord. So all the preachers went on confessing, each one worst than the last. Finally they came to the last preacher who had been very quiet and listening to every word that fell. One of the preachers said to him, it's your turn. Confessing will lift you burden, Brother. Bare us your soul. We did. The last preacher said, no, my sin is the worst among all of you. One of the preachers said, ah go on man and stop all this suspense. So the last preacher said, like I told you my sin is the lowest.  (beat) My sin is gossiping and I can't wait to get out and tell what I heard. Sunny does not get the humor of the story. He is more interested in picking up his marbles that Gideon's foot kicked over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oughtn't tell him stories like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me another story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll you a story about the terrapin and the rabbit. No, you tell me a story. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, my mommy and daddy lived in this big house that I bought for them. I got them this big car. A strong wind causes the broom handle to knock against th china teapot, KNOCKING IT TO THE FLOOR. Suzie stops Sunny from trying to help pick up the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay back. You might cut your fingers. Suzie looks down sadly at her broken tea pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked everywhere for my toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees are barren, which gives them an unfriendly look we LOOK at the ground, a man's distorted shadow stops in frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow of a man appears on Gideon's porch. The camera t up to HARRY MENTION, a very dark-looking, ageless old man carrying several boxes held together by a cord. He looks exhausted from his journey. He looks in his address book satisfied that he reached the right house, he rings the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie comes to the front door; she recognizes Harry right away. She invites him in. Harry stumps his feet on the po several times and then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, I can't believe it is you. Gideon, look who is here. Gideon comes in, wiping his hands. Sunny, carrying the br follows behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, good God Almighty, man! It's been, what, thirty years or more. Suzie, we haven't seen Harry since we left home. Harry is more interested in the boy, but Sunny doesn't wa to come near Harry. It is Gideon's arm that is keeping hi within close range of Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my grandson, Sunny. He is my youngest son's child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kind of favors one of my boys when he was about his age. Sunny, playing with the broom, accidentally touches Harry shoe with it. Harry hides his anger about being touched w the broom. Harry takes the broom from Sunny and spits on bottom of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, that is bad luck to touch a fellow with a broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows better. Sunny, apologize to Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in these parts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came all the way from Detroit by bus going to Oakland. The bus stopped in Los Angeles. I had to get off and take a rest. I'll catch the last bus leaving at midnight. I'm just too tired to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you catch a plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feet have never been on anything that wasn't directly attached to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay until you feel better? I would like to hear all the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worn out but won't you feel like you are taking in a stranger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stranger my foot, it was my grandmother who helped you into this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to put you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, put your boxes down and stay as long as you like. We have empty rooms since the boys got their own families and moved out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if you're sure, I won't be a bother. Oh, I don't sleep on no spring mattress. I always make myself a pallet on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom door to Harry's room is cracked open. Peering through the cracked door, we SEE Harry asleep on his pall His back is turned to the camera. It is dead silent. Ther does not seem to be any sign of life. On the floor is a p that has water in it. It looks like it is for a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is peeling potatoes and Gideon is ironing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor old Harry, he really must have been worn out. He has been asleep all day. Without anyone being aware, Harry has been standing in th doorway for some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. It must be all the different time zones I crossed that makes me feel this weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go back and rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if I rest any longer, I won't sleep tonight. May I use your bathroom to wash up a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, act like this is your home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's awful generous of you. I always ask to keep from wearing out welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One can tell you are from back home. These people nowadays don't know what manners are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we come from, you had to know how to act right. You had to know how to say yes sir and no sir. You had to know your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had to tread softly. The doorbell rings and Gideon goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those days you could always find something redeeming about even the worst person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember that boy who lost his mind, Joe? You could hear him pitching horseshoes at night in the dark. He wouldn't miss a one. Make him mad and call yourself running in the house to be safe. He would pick up a brick and say "go on in there brick and hit somebody" and it would find its mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was afraid to go to Marcus Bottom because of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those places that us coloreds lived, that we used to call Bottoms, have all been changed to Drives and Heights. Everything is in what you call it, not in what it is. Gideon comes back with Junior, Pal and Rhonda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, I would like for you to meet my oldest son, his wife and daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. So you're from back home, too. Harry and Junior shake hands, but Rhonda gives Harry only nod of her head and a smile. Pat, who is pregnant, attempts to shake hands with Harry, is forced to withdraw her hand because of a sudden pain i her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy must be turning over. Oh, he just kicked me again. Junior feels her stomach. Pat again tries to shake Harry' hand and again gets a jolt from her stomach. She finds a chair to sit down in. The SOUND of rocks hitting the roof causes everyone to lo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the boy next door throwing at his birds. I'm just waiting on him to hit a pane in the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to wash up now. You all please excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is wiping off his face with a washcloth. He stares himself in the mirror for a long time. The sudden sound o the boy next door starting to play his trumpet startles h He smiles at the trumpeter's efforts. He wrings the wash cloth out. A reddish oil-like liquid D into the face bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few of the houses have lights on. Suddenly, Gideon's rooster starts to CROW. A dog starts to bark and a garbag can is knocked over. Bedroom lights in almost all the hou in the neighborhood pop on. The voices of neighbors complaining are heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is just waking up. He listens to the voices of Suzi and Gideon as they get ready for church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is paging through the Bible as he stands by the do waiting for Suzie who is watering her plants. Harry comes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to come hear our preacher. Remember old Cat Iron? Well, our preacher is just as strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time when I feel a little better perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to get up and get a hen out there for dinner, but time got away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I would feel much at home if you let me get one for you. I haven't wrung a chicken's neck in a month of Sundays. You know, folks would call my daddy to kill their hogs. That used to be my trade from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I would appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon and Suzie are stepping off the porch. Harry is standing behind the screen door. Gideon and Suzie get in Junior's car. Junior, Pat and Rho wave to Harry as the car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry looks through Gideon's and Suzie's private things. looks at the baby pictures that fill the mirror. He reads Suzie's letters that are dated years ago. In one of the letters, he finds a picture of a man standing behind a plough. "Uncle Joe after Ella's death" is written on the back. A picture of a mule holds his interest. He looks at for a long time and carries it with him as he continues h search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry slowly walks along the rows in Suzie's garden. He stands by the chicken cage. Suddenly, the chickens start run about and CACKLE as if a dog had gotten in. Harry turns from the chicken coop. He stands still. Sunny hiding behind a bush. Sunny steps around the bush. Harry looks at Sunny with su concentration that Sunny takes a step backward as if gett ready to defend himself. MRS. BAKER, a black woman in her early thirties, comes ou the back porch. She shakes out a rug. She stops shaking t rug and stares at Harry. Harry becomes aware of Mrs. Baker's stare. He comes to himself and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Babe Brother are playing cards while Linda watc and Sunny plays by himself on the floor. In the sink is a newspaper full of bloody feathers. A small flame is under pot on the stove. Harry looks at the chicken in the pot a sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't act like the rest of Gideon's friends. They believe if you are not hard at work, you are hard at sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm more modern in my ways. I don't believe in sin, though there is good and evil.  (beat) And evil is a thing you work at. Harry takes his knife, a crab apple switch, out. It has a rabbit foot attached to it. Harry cleans his fingernail w the knife. Sunny is interested in the rabbit foot. He rea for the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you mustn't touch. Your mama might not like you handling knives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he wants to see your rabbit foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I let this rabbit foot do in place of my toby that I lost years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a toby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to be at crossroads without one. It's a charm that old people teach you how to make. I had one for a long time that belonged to my grandmother who had it ever since she was a child.  (beat) In my travels I misplaced it. I have been looking over my shoulder ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't old fashioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In some things. When we were children, there used to be an old man that came around and would snatch your soul if you didn't have something on you that didn't make a X. Harry is aware that Babe Brother is interested in the kni After cleaning his last fingernail, he hands the knife to Babe Brother. Harry looks at the cards in his hand. He smiles to himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have your child at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. No. No. I had my Child at Cedars and Sinai. And that ain't no county hospital. You have to have cash or check before you come in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some folks take that natural stuff too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior's wife kept her afterbirth' in the refrigerator. That's why I do not eat over there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Country people got so many strange ways, Harry looks again at the chicken that he is boiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever have to use this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is called a crab apple switch. It's for those bad acting monkeys and just the thing for a mean dog. Now I don't know if I actually did what I did or got my life and story mixed in with other folk's stories but I seem to recall that I had to use my crab apple on a boy from back home. I was up in Memphis working on the railroad, like your daddy who had an easy job. He would sing a song that had a cadence and we would lay track. Anyway I was coming down Beale Street and I heard this music coming from a saloon. Sure enough it was Emory. My daddy taught both of us to play but Emory was natural at it. Got in a blues band and what not. He and another boy had killed a boy named Hocker sometime back and they balled the Jack leaving town. Emory had lost one eye and had a scar running down his face. Bad luck I would say. He got to drinking that corn liquor. We went to his girl's room and he wouldn't stop drinking. He started talking about the old days and he went mad. He pulled his knife and I got to mine first. The lights went out. Linda picks up a card and looks at it. There is a naked w on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pick up the cards if you are not in the game. Did he die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened to him. He just ran out into the streets.  (beat) I got some old records I want you to hear. I like the blues sung simply, man and a guitar. Or sung by a woman who had bad luck all her life. Don't ever let anyone tell you his life's story if it is of a weary life full of sadness. When I was a boy, a man told me a story of how he lost all of his sons and I'll be damned if the same thing didn't happen to me. Sunny is busy playing in the curtains. The SOUND of Gideon and Suzie arriving makes them scurry get the cards put away. Harry puts his knife away just as Suzie and Gideon enter. Linda feels a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was church? Gideon and Suzie are surprised to see Linda. They don't k what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodney walks around in the yard BLOWING his trumpet as lo as he can. The SOUND of the trumpet frightens Skip's bird

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is repairing the pipes under the face bowl. Harry leaning against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often is your wife called to help delivery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was slow. Now it seems like everyone is having births at home. Gideon takes the pipe off. It has rotted. Gideon cannot believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could have caused this? I just changed this damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything these days is made overseas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Babe Brother hit it off so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course, it is your business, but I feel obliged to tell you that maybe you have not been fair with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to teach him right from wrong just like I did his Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has to follow his own plough. A man doesn't have to know how to cut a wick and clean a chimney nowadays. City people don't give a hoot and a holler about the shape of the moon nowadays. You don't plant old ways... (beat) ... but, at the end, you find yourself doing what your father did but you have to have the land in you. (beat) It's when you want to give the house or farm to the kids and they don't want it. You sell it to a stranger. You worked your whole life, for what? (beat) I doubt if people nowadays have knowledge of a victory garden or seen an inch worm. All what we've experienced has no meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're suppose to teach your children what you know. Junior, I don't have to worry about. Babe Brother is a different story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still call him boy. You call Babe Brother boy in front of his wife and son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy called me boy up to the time he died. I was always boy to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course, you could be right. Your sons are alive. All my sons are dead. Off-screen, Rodney starts to practice on his HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is sitting with Sunny by the screen door blo giant bubbles. The bubbles drift past Linda, who is sitti at the table with real estate papers all over the table. is talking on the phone with a client and signals them to stop disturbing her. Babe Brother sends more bubbles floating by, causing her shake the water off her papers while she talks to a first time buyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has three bedrooms, one and a half baths. Well, yes, that means two toilets and one bath. Well... Yes, by appointment... Call me back if you decide. She hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would think people never lived in a house if they have to ask what does 1 1/2 baths mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you still get the money from your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him we might not need it, if you can talk your parents into giving you your share of the property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pops put Big Daddy's farm in Rhonda's and Sunny's name and fixed it so no one can borrow on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could borrow on that land and put the money to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I preached to Mom and Dad about it but they are stuck in their ways, it's like talking to a brick. But if there is a way... Babe Brother is lost in his thoughts. He stares down at h hands resting on his knees. He picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is on the phone with Babe Brother. Pat crosses in front of the camera shaking her head in a negative manner Babe Brother's voice is just audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to mortgage my house to invest in a scheme of yours? You know the last time we went into something together Daddy had to go in his savings to keep us from ending on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you always afraid to get somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a good time to take chances. Your best friend, Robert, an accountant, lost his home and is out on the street. We see him from time to time. He comes down to church for a free meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what it is all about, trying to keep from being out on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert asks about you. When are you going to do something to help him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I can get down there next week. Junior turns to his wife, who is off-camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother always acts like a gambler who is in the biggest game of his life and don't know about playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry and Gideon are walking along a railroad track. The is blinding. The heat makes the asphalt Appear to turn in lake off in the distance. Gideon appears exhausted; beads sweat continually form on his forehead. He fans himself w his hat. Harry is unaffected by the hot temperature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can sit here and look at train tracks all day. We laid enough of them, didn't we? So many memories are stretched along tracks like these. Gideon looks down the tracks. A bowl of dust stirs off in distance. The hot temperature makes the tracks appear liq

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tracks begin to twist and bend. Off in the distance, faint images of men laying track to a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is standing with his hat in his hand. His posture that of an extremely old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In weather like this, you cannot walk around bare-headed. He wipes the sweat from his hat band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go a little farther. The walk will do us some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is peeling apples while Sunny, standing next to her catches peelings in his mouth. Pat is sitting next to the window. She is uncomfortable. She loosens her pants, givi her stomach more room. Rhonda is leaning over the back of chair with her arms around Pat's neck. They are in silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do your homework?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I name the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie knocks on the door. Harry comes to the door still buttoning his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have someone I want you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon in the background in the kitchen washing off the vegetables. Suzie and HATTIE are sitting at the table. Ha comes in and is surprised to see Hat tie. Hattie is in he late sixties but looks well. She makes a conscious effort dress plainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it when Suzie called and said you were staying here. How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl, do you still sing and dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm a different person now, Harry. Hattie has a nervous condition that causes her to squint time to time. Gideon comes in from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't the years been good to Hattie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hasn't been the years; it's been the men in her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, that's not nice. I'm in church now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why run out and close the barn door when the horse is gone? I remember when you weren't saved. That was way back yonder when the Natchez Trace was just a dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people grow up and change their ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your mother ain't still operating that house of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother passed on years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. slams the door to his car and hurries up the steps, leaving HERMAN, in spite of his bad condition, to get out the car the best he can. The car door almost knocks poor Herman over. M.C. seems rather youthful because of his en and awkwardness. He is a large muscular man. Herman is a dried-up man with nothing, not even a shadow. has a racking COUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. gives Gideon a bear hug, lifting him off his feet. O seeing Suzie, he drops Gideon and rushes over to lift her off her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman is still trying to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. lifts Suzie off the ground twice. He runs over to Ha who does not want to be handled, tries to withdraw but M. forces her to her feet and gives a big bear hug. Hattie h series of squinting attacks. M.C. squints in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C., you still ain't house broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God Almighty, if it ain't like a parade of people from out of the past. M.C., where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live here. There is a TAPPING on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's old Herman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, what did you do, rob the graveyard? Herman hobbles in and, after a minute of COUGHING, a smil forms on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Gideon and Hattie are seated at the table while M. bounces from one end of the table to the other. One momen is on his knees and next moment he is leaning over someon flick his ashes in the ashtray on the table. Hattie hates when he comes near her. Harry and Herman sit together in the corner chewing on starch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie, do you still dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, you still have Joe's number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will have to look for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a boy from home, Lulla's brother. Suzie is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, you know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to know everything, do everything, and be everything. Gideon brings a fresh pot of coffee. Gideon tries to sign M.C. to stop harassing Hattie. M.C. leans over Hattie aga to use the ashtray. Harry is helping Herman to his feet. Herman starts to cou They come over and join the rest of the crowd at the tabl Harry seats Herman next to Gideon and pours Herman a cup coffee. He puts the sugar and cream in the coffee for Her Suzie comes back with Joe's number and hands it to Hattie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C., I'm worn out. You ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are tired, go sit in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, do you have any Swamp Root?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I might have some Indian Chief Tonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't heard anyone mention Swamp Root since button-up shoes went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can certainly tell how old you are, my dear. Hattie is angered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the saying, "your heart is in your left hand."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I was trying to be nice, to make conversation, since we go back some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was quoting from the Bible. If the shoe fits, wear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Out of weariness, I spoke to my own heart; to leave it all and to die. And I gave my heart to know madness and folly."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't going to win playing the dozens with Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all ought to get along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, you know you remind me of so much that went wrong in my life. When I heard you were here, I made a special effort to come and see you. I see you are still a pile of wet chicken feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister, women can get away with so much. I don't have any enemies 'cause I don't live in the past. As Pushkin, you don't know him, said, "In the hope of glory and good, I look without fear ahead."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry has got your number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty wagon makes a lot of noise and you, tappy head, you ain't worth the salt you put in greens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of tappy heads, we ought to have an old fashion fish fry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have too many fish fries left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can have it here next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry. Gideon, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's up to Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime Harry can slaughter us a hog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, M.C., take me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children of the women in Suzie's natural birth group huddled together SINGING "Ashiine Ca Chew". The voices of women in the next room are audible. The kids go outside t sit on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the women have their newborns with them and are engaging in talk about how their other children had to ad and etc. A young white mother, REBECCA WILSON, with both her child a four year old and one just a few months old, talks with deep southern accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one in my family ever been to a hospital to give birth. My sister has four children and all were born at home. My mother and her mother, it just goes on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mother leaves with her baby wrapped in a blanket. The k surround her, wanting to see the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat is looking at a book of baby names. Harry passes the and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman in family way just reminds of spring and my younger days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you and your husband are special. Ya, Gideon tells me you do volunteer work to help feed the poor. Pat beams with joy because Harry recognizes the important work she is doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many people do you all feed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last Saturday we handed out over two hundred meals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God Almighty, bless your bones. (pause) But the problem grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Week by week the crowds at the door keeps getting larger. We can't feed all the hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. Have you ever heard of a man jumping in the river to save five hundred drowning people? No you ain't. (pause) You have to take just one and fatten him up. When you spread help too thin, you , you just nickel and dime the situation. If you try to save all, all die but if you save one life, life goes on. You just have to remember, medicine that works leaves a bitter taste. Harry looks at the baby picture pasted over the mirror. H takes the picture of his children from his old black dust wallet and compares the faces of his kids with those on t mirror. He talks to himself more than to Pat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just take one; you thaw out the cold and hunger in his bones from sleeping on the bare ground. Pat watches him and loses herself in what he is doing. Sh responds automatically

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if we could take one in with Rhonda and me at home alone at times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wasn't pointing my finger at you. Hey, you have to think of yourself. A lot of them have all kinds of diseases and will cut your throat while you sleep. There are too many bad people out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is taking the back door off to paint. Harry helps carry the door and lay it on a saw horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate you lending me a hand. That lazy ass brother of mine was suppose to help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well some folks are still waiting for their comeuppance. Don't take me wrong but you can't judge people by how you act. You're a caring person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be caring. That is not too much to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya, but you can't do the shuffle with one leg. You and your wife, in your spare time, work with the less fortunate. Now I'm not talking about you and what you do but some folks that always run to help the victim, deep down are attracted to pain and suffering and love to be near the dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the people working with us are really doing it 'cause they hate to see suffering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know what's in the heart and just because you can cry doesn't make you human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda is in the background washing dishes. Pat and Junio are sitting at the dining room table, arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't really bring another family in here with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Harry says that's the only way to do good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you talk to Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shout!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon and Sunny are in the garden digging for worms. The chickens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have enough. So now tell me a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is sitting on a rock by the lake. His image is reflected in the lake. He is asleep. Sunny is putting new bait on one of the reels and with a whip of the pole, he casts to the center of the lake. He leans against a tree. Sunny looks at his sleeping grandfather. Gideon has his p legs rolled up. His socks have lost their elastic. His he is resting on his chest. Sunny goes near the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful of the water. Sunny looks back at his grandfather, who appears to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one fish in the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon and Sunny are sitting next to each other. The lake reflects the sky: a deep red. The eerie sound of a long t whistle breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, Babe Brother and Linda come in after staying out a night. Linda looks as though she is about to fall asleep standing up. She awakes and looks at Harry. There is disl in her stare. Suzie and Gideon notice Linda fading away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been so tired in my life. Where is Sunny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is getting his things together. Babe Brother, you ought to take your wife home so she can get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute. Sunny comes in carrying his night-clothes folded neatly. stands next to Linda. Harry, in a mild but demanding way, ushers Babe Brother out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your wife and child home, boy. Babe Brother seems all too happy to obey Harry. After Har closes the door behind Babe Brother, he turns with a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a surprise for you tonight. Harry flops down on the couch and kicks his shoes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This old buffalo has been in the sun too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie and Gideon are getting the food ready while Harry, wearing a shirt that looks like it is made of shiny snakeskin, sits in a darkened corner of the room, cutting fingernails with his knife. The door bell rings and Harry slowly walks over to answer door. Suzie puts the punch bowl down and hurries over to the first guests, FRED JENKINS, an elderly black man whom hasn't seen in years, and Esme Jenkins, his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred Jenkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, you haven't changed and you, Gideon, if you don't look like John Henry. Oh, this is my wife, Esme. My first wife Lulie died. More people arrive, bottle-necking the doorway. Gideon he the Jenkinses to a chair. Hattie comes with her brother MARSH, who is not too pleased to see Harry. OKRA TATE, an elderly black man with dark circles under his eyes, comes limping badly with an old Polaroid camera hanging from hi neck. Babe Brother, Linda, Junior, Pat and Rhonda, who is holdi Sunny's hand, all come in together. M.C. drags Herman thr the door coughing. FLIM ANDERSON and his son DOUG are followed by the twins, WILLIAM and LOVIRAY NORWOOD, who a in their late 70's. Babe Brother leaves Linda standing by herself to be next Harry. Zenia Dent, an elderly white woman with a strong Southern accent, arrives with her husband, Howard Dent, a black ma who is in a wheelchair. The Twins and Howard are the cent of attention. Okra comes over and whispers into Harry's ear. Okra leave through the front door. Okra comes back in with a bag. Ha Babe Brother, M.C. and Herman follow Okra to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okra sets the bag on the table and steps back to allow Ha to unveil the bottle of corn liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, that is the real South. That is real corn liquor. A crowd starts to gather around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is in the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't Geritol. M.C. starts to hand out tea cups while Harry pours everyo drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a fight in every bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tappy heads better not tear down my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive Woman, in her younger days a knockout, puts a record and starts to pop her fingers to the music as sh moves towards the center of the floor dancing by herself, inviting anyone bold enough to join her. A group of Men who haven't seen each other in years are asking questions about news of old friends. Okra is trying to get his camera working. Herman is following M.C. through the crowd with his hand resting on M.C.'s shoulder as if he were a blind person. racking COUGH is frightening. An older couple dancing attract the attention of the crow The man is wearing Stacy Adams shoes polished to see one' face in them. He gives expression to his moves as if he a the woman are talking with their bodies. Junior and Pat try to bring in something more modern to o the older couple. Herman corners Hattie, trying to get her to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you better get out of my face before I slap the living daylights out of you. Harry stops the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks excuse me but you know we have a celebrity from out of the past, our own nightingale. If you had any good times in your life, you remember Hattie. She use to keep those juke joints steaming. If Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith were the stars, she was the sun. Let's get Hattie to sing something from the old days. Hattie has started her nervous twitch again. She is so ma that she bites her lip to keep from exploding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry always tries to be the king fish. I told him I'm a new person. I'm saved. Harry signals an old man, PERCY, to start playing his gui Percy starts to play but Hattie doesn't join him. He look Harry for a sign of what to do. Hattie walks away. Percy starts to SING by himself but someone puts a record interrupting his singing. People are back to dancing. A YOUNGER WOMAN is dancing with an OLDER MAN with such vi forcing the old man to try to keep up, that people grow concerned. People near him try to make him slow down but pride forces him to be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda sits with Sunny and Rhonda watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise has gotten louder, everyone talking at the top his voice. Gideon is busy going around to everyone seeing if everyth is okay. Gideon and Suzie have worked up a sweat trying t attend to everyone's needs. Linda rejoins the party. She moves through the crowd and Babe Brother standing next to Harry. She is disappointed stays at a distance. Harry is with a group of people. Marsh tries to get Harry attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, you will not remember me but we go back quite a ways. I'm glad Hattie told me that you will be here 'cause there is a matter that has been troubling me all these years that maybe you can help me clear it up. Harry stares into Marsh's eyes, then looks him over from to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I can't talk to you now. I'm filling in the gaps with these folks. Harry turns his back on Marsh. Marsh stands there looking Harry's profile. He turns and walks away. The record ends. The Younger Woman and the Older Man wait the next record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you manage to keep in step and move around so like one of them young boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get yourself a pace-maker like me. Linda is standing by herself. She watches Babe Brother an Harry walk towards the kitchen. Pat comes to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These old folks can dance better than I can. Get rid of that long face. Get one of these old farts to show you how to do the Black Bottom. Okra, holding his camera, all of the attachments in one h and a glass in his other hand, tries to offer Hattie a dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so stand-offish. Hattie pushes him away. The drink spills on him. She turn and walks away. He follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh sits in a chair opposite Harry. Babe Brother stands behind Harry. Harry, knowing that Marsh is going to bring unpleasant things of the past, feels the need to get rid Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you haven't danced with your wife all night. Babe Brother is reluctant to leave, but Harry gives him a nudge. He goes looking for Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something that I always wanted to know. Tell me, how did those boys die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Clara's boy, Emory, to start with. The Johnson's Hocker was another one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't Hocker lynched?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know as well as I do that it was made to look like he was lynched. Now who would hang someone from a persimmon tree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make if it's persimmon, oak tree or huckleberry bush?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon, Babe Brother, and Linda go outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of the party drift out from the house as Gideo Linda and Babe Brother talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, how come me and Suzie have to be mother and father to your child? You never take the boy to the park, circus or anything. If we did not take him to church, he wouldn't have any sense of religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think forcing him to go to church when he really doesn't understand is not saving his soul. When he gets old enough to make up his own mind about religion, that will be better. It will be his intellectual decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the way your parents raised you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you don't want us to bring him over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior spends time with his child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh here we go with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okra is trying to get enough light for his old Polaroid camera. M.C. takes a shade off a lamp and holds it next t the Twins, nearly blinding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up and take this picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it wasn't for the NRA, colored people would have been the lost tribe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what they use to call the NRA? Negro Raggedy-ass Army. M.C. is still holding the naked lamp while Okra tries to pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hocker's death almost caused a race riot. A lot of innocent people could have been hurt behind that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange as it may seem, it might have cleared the waters. Sometimes the right action comes from the wrong reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon, Babe Brother and Linda are just standing, facing another. Suzie comes out on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want your coat? It's cold out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm too hot now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better be careful. You'll get a stroke arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't care if I drop dead if he learn something from it.  (beat) Son, you make me wish I was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon, don't say things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he always pick on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is just being like all parents, concerned about the ones they love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need that kind of love. And I don't want to be reminded all the time that Big Mama's grandmother was born in slavery. If you really care about me, just tell me how I can make money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother, I'm going to take my hand and hit you across your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't mean what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us go back in before the night of celebration becomes a night of me killing my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Before anyone moves, you two shake hands and don't carry it any further. Linda gives Babe Brother a jab with her elbow. His hand reaches out to Gideon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. and Herman put the unshaded lamps next to Hattie so can get a better picture. Percy starts to play his guitar Herman stands behind Percy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me say something nasty now. Percy starts to play an old religious number and Hattie STARTS TO SING. Everything stops for a moment as her VOIC fills the room. Then most of the guests pick up and join in. M.C. moves t lamp next to Percy so Okra can take his picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsh and Harry are getting quite loud in their argument. has become a kind of controlled anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think if anybody had a hand in killing Hocker, you ought to ask or you should have asked Emory and Chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chick was outright killed by a mob. He killed a white man that owed him some money and when they caught up with him, they tied him behind a car and dragged him from out of the hills back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those boys never did have good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You damn right they didn't, especially Emory, my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emory had made a lot of enemies. He had a big mouth. M.C. and Okra come in wanting to take pictures. Marsh is pretty mad about them intruding. M.C. sets the naked lamp front of Marsh, on the floor, almost between his legs. Before Okra can get his camera set to shoot, Marsh leaves Harry smiles as if he had won a major victory. Herman flo down in the empty chair and starts to COUGH. Suddenly Suzie and Gideon burst into the kitchen holding one of the twins, Loviray. They carry the twin towards Herman's seat. Herman is slow to react. Herman gets up ve slow. Finally, they are able to seat the twin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a fish bone caught in her throat. Could all of you go in the other room? Gideon, get some bread and toast it quickly and find me the cod liver oil. The twin is holding her throat and PANTING like a fish ou water. She is in a lot of pain. William, the twin brother standing at the door with a tragic face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is trying to get out of bed. He sits on the side o the bed and starts to COUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry has his back to the camera, sitting in a chair faci wall. He is naked from the waist up. An empty plate is pl not too far from where he is sitting. He is cutting an ap He licks the blade of his knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is asleep. Linda is dressed to go to work. S throws his suit on the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to work or sleep all day? He snores louder. She opens the window and pulls back the cover. The cold air makes him draw up. On walking out, Li says in a rather hurt voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, you promised to take Sunny to Magic Mountain today. Babe Brother slowly gets up holding his chest as if his h is bothering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon tries to put his pants on. He is too weak and sits back on the bed with his pants only up as far as his knee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie gets up to turn off the coffee kettle. When the ket WHISTLE dies away, the sound of Gideon's VOICE is heard calling Suzie for help. The sound of his voice frightens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie bursts into the room and then moves very slowly to Gideon, who is sitting on the bed out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worn out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay in bed and rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to feed the chickens before they wake everybody up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay inside. I will see to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie and Junior are sitting at the dining room table. Ha looking like he has just gotten out of bed, drags himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolerable well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you sleep last night? There is obvious hostility in Junior's tone. Harry senses Junior's hostility and chooses to ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you young folks don't know how it is. How is Gideon today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't able to get out of bed today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that it's nothing serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has never gotten rid of the malaria. He is usually up and at it the next day. I'm going to make him fresh chicken broth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me earn my keep. I'll go out and get a hen and have it picked and ready for the pot. Try to make him some cow tea next time. Junior stares at Harry. Harry returns Junior's stare and Junior finds himself embarrassed. Junior looks down at hi pants leg and attempts to fix the crease in his pants by making a wedge with his fingers and running his fingers a the old crease. As Harry walks towards the back door, he looks back at Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pigeons take to the air like an explosion. The chicke start to CACKLE and run about as Harry reaches for one wi his cane. The SOUND of the boy next door practicing with trumpet adds to the bedlam. Suzie is standing on the steps, shouting to Harry. The no of the panicked chickens and the boy playing the trumpet door drown out Suzie's voice. Not getting Harry's attenti she hurries down the steps. Harry has caught a hen that is SCREAMING her head off. He looks around and finds Suzie hurrying towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you watch Gideon for a while? One of the girls is going into labor. Junior is going to drive me over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just run along. I'll fix him his soup. He will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie and another woman who will be helping her are aslee Suzie is in the chair and the woman is asleep on the floo The woman who is in labor is reading a magazine and seems somewhat bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
