dialogues.text: Harry opens the door and slowly walks in. Gideon is aslee Harry picks up Gideon's pants from the back of the chair. Gideon's false teeth fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flurry of activity; the woman is contracting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The untouched chicken broth sits on the night stand. Gide is TALKING in his sleep. Morning light filters through th window shade. The room takes on a brownish tint. Gideon h dark rings under his eyes and looks like he has aged considerably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is reading the Bible. He runs his finger over the p of the Bible. After reading the passage, he stares at the empty plate on the floor for what seems like a long time. claps the Bible shut, causing a loud NOISE to ECHO throug the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is walking slowly up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie raises the window shade and is shocked to see the s that Gideon is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is crowded with people. Suzie is putting Gideon' shirt on. Harry is leaning against the door. After having his shirt on, Suzie puts his house shoes on and directs B Brother and Junior to hold him up while she tucks his shi in and puts on his suspenders. It takes almost everyone to hoist Gideon. Linda and Pat p the bed and night-stand out of the way as Babe Brother an Junior struggle to lift Gideon. They almost stumble at th door. Harry is left standing in the room alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, Okra and Herman are trying to catch another chicke Herman is COUGHING badly and Okra is out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think old Gideon is going to live to see this month out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I came upon the valley of bones, the serpent said, "Make this your home. Dry as my soul be, heaven is lost to thee." We all got to make way. Harry puts the rooster face to the ground and draws a straight line. Harry lets the rooster go, but the rooster stays motionless, unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chicken hates to see the preacher coming to dinner. Herman hands Harry the ax. Harry is poised over the chick with the ax, appreciating the moment. Harry raises the ax The SOUND of Rodney starting to practice his trumpet brin the rooster out of the trance. Before Harry can react, the rooster jumps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman, you will have to catch the next one 'cause I'm out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I have to chase after one, we won't eat. A sack drops over the fence. Okra limps over to see what in the bag. He uses a stick to open the bag. He doesn't l what he sees and throws the bag back over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Junior and Pat are standing around Gideon's bed. H in a room full of old veterans who are apparently nearing end. Two old veterans, one white and the other black, sitting opposite each other wearing medals, sit in silence starin into each other's eyes. A nurse empties an old man's urine bag. The old man doesn show any embarrassment about his predicament. Gideon look how the patients are treated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay here.  (beat) Where is Babe Brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. is sitting on the bed, reading the job section of th paper. Herman is putting Vicks Vapo-Rub in a bowl of boil water. He covers his head over the bowl with a towel. Okr sitting at the table examining his gun. He points it at t floor, seeing if the sight is straight. Harry is sitting at the table with Babe Brother. Harry is showing him how to cheat at cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never play with someone's else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this card. See anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is just a regular card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, I can take everything you got with that deck. It is marked. Now I'm going to show you how to make some money in case you get stuck somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moth flies around the light casting a shadow that float over everything. Suzie turns out the kitchen light and th turns out the dining-room light. She goes to her room and closes the door, leaving the room dark. A car headlight passing outside casts a moving pattern that moves along t wall. The light reveals Harry's presence standing in the hall doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is being helped up the steps by his sons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is holding the door open while Gideon is carried in Junior and Babe Brother. Gideon is led to a chair. He sti looks awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't he look a whole of lot better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you look better than you did yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, I don't care how sick I'll be, don't take me back to the Veteran's Hospital. Harry comes out of the bathroom, having just taken a bath Harry seems delighted to see Gideon again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I thought you were about to cross the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I feel like a ghost. Harry signals Babe Brother to come over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, would you do me a favor and see if you could turn off that tap in the bathroom. My hand is too weak. And would you do me another favor? I don't like asking this but would you clean the tub for me? I have trouble bending over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime you need someone to do something for you, just let me know. Harry flops down on the couch. Suzie sets a cup of coffee the table for Gideon. Harry looks up from sharpening his knife on a hand sharpening stone. He spits on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That smells like fresh coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get you a cup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you can spare it. Junior stands over Harry's shoulder looking at him sharpe his knife. Harry feels uncomfortable with Junior standing behind him. Harry looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, would you get me an old piece of newspaper? Suzie sets a cup of coffee in front of Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord if you ain't an angel. Junior hands Harry the newspaper. Harry puts the paper un his foot and trims his toenails with it. Harry is aware o Junior standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will leave you something in my will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior looks in but Babe Brother is too busy trying to cl the bathtub to notice anyone. Babe Brother complains to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon and Suzie are in silhouette against the window. The SOUND of the boy trying to play his horn next door startles Gideon. Gideon turns to look out of the window towards Mrs. Baker's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to be able to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have been really sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the garden doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get out there and get those weeds out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that hen doing? I was meaning to pip her before I fell sick. He takes a deep breath and blows it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to lie down. Take my, hand and help me up, lest I fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie helps Gideon to undress. Gideon loses hit balance b catches himself on the side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't have last another day in that hospital. You get weary being in the old soldiers home, old soldiers and war stories. They wait to tell you their last story; the next morning the nurse pulls a sheet over their face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is putting up a new light fixture. Pat hands him a tool. Rhonda is washing dishes in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just leeches off your parents. He is a master at wearing out welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is the kind of guy you would love to take out in the woods and leave under a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does her get the power to summon all his old raffish friends? They all smell of moth balls.  Junior slips on the ladder and the wires touch. There is big spark. All the lights in the house go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is standing over the stove, sweating as she stirs a pot of boiling soup. Babe Brother and Harry are seated at the table playing ca Sunny is on the floor near his mother. Every time she mov he follows her. Harry notices Sunny has his shoes on the wrong foot and adds in a sarcastic way:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is that boy? Babe Brother looks at Sunny's shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, how come you don't see that Sunny puts his shoes on right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the h... Close to tears, she turns and with exaggerated care, puts spoon down and gently puts Sunny in a chair. She starts t untie his shoes. Sunny stares at her while she keeps wipi her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's give Dry Bones a call to see if he is coming or not. Okra likes to exaggerate, keep you waiting all night. Harry slowly gets to his feet and goes in the other room use the phone. Linda watches him go. She is deep in thoug Babe Brother, attempting to cut the roast before it is re is pushed aside by Linda, who is almost out of control wi rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you wait? Babe Brother, attempting to forcibly cut a piece of roast slings Linda's arm away. His hand accidentally hits her i the eye. Linda grabs the fork, poised to strike, but gains control herself She looks like a person who is on the verge of ha a breakdown. She goes back to putting the shoes on Sunny. Babe Brother, feeling sorry, doesn't know what to do. He automatically picks up the fork and washes it off. Linda picks up Sunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is standing at the door, with a red eye, welcoming Harry's friends, which seem to be a long line of sickly people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is busy serving everyone, running in and out of the kitchen bringing more things, and removing used plates, e Linda's eye is swollen and discolored. The guests look at Linda's eye and then cast a naughty-boy glance at Babe Brother. Linda stops serving to pay attention to an elderly man, w deliberately bends one of her spoons. She catches another putting a fork in his pocket and an elderly lady putting cigarette out in one of her plates. As she is about to confront the man about pocketing her spoon, a peal of LAUGHTER forces her to turn around only witness a lady knocking over a glass filled with a green drink with her elbow. The stain spreads across the table cloth in an even manner like a single wave. She watches i move from one end of the table to the other. Harry is seated in the middle. The composition hints at T Last Supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is reading a book to Sunny, who has his coffee can marbles emptied on the bed. The NOISE from the party in t next room is clearly heard. Every time she hears somethin CRASHING to the floor, she wrenches. Babe Brother comes i and stands in the doorway. Linda's eye is still swollen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. Go back to your friends. Babe Brother closes the door and leaves Linda reading sto of Brer Rabbit to Sunny. She stops reading to look at him playing marbles on the bed. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five weighty Women, dressed in church robes, and the Prea walk up Gideon's steps. Suzie invites the church members in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister, we've come to see how you were doing. We came to ask if we could pray over Gideon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is asleep. The church members gather around his be The Preacher puts his hand on the foot of the bed and discovers that there is something strange under the cover Suzie looks at him and lifts the covers at the foot of th bed. Gideon's feet are resting on dead leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put some Plummer Christian Leaves under his feet to draw the fever out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else have you been giving him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I crossed his stomach with cold oil and gave him some cow tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, I would think you would depend on prayer rather than these old fashion remedies. Let us read from the Bible. The Preacher opens his Bible and reads silently. The choi HUMS and begin to sway. Gideon's SNORING is very competit The choir becomes louder. Gideon starts to TALK in his sl Suzie is alarmed. CLOSE UP GIDEON'S EAR. THE SOUND OF A TRAIN WHISTLE IS HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lady steps upon the stage which has different backdrops She is the same lady in a photo that Gideon has hanging i one of the kid's rooms. The photographer, who is off-scre asks about the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scene would you like in the background?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have plantations. The woman shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natchez, cotton fields, Harlem, sunflowers, the Mississippi River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the river behind me. A large picture of the Mississippi appears behind the lad It changes from a painted backdrop to a moving picture. T is a storm developing off in the distance. The SOUND of thunder is heard. The picture in the background then chan to a boy on a mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy on the gray mule doesn't have a shirt on. A light mist like rain covers him. Gideon walks along the picket fence towards the boy on the mule. Ahead of Gideon seems to be a puddle but as he approaches discovers that it is an abyss. The boy and the mule on th other side fade away. Everything FADES TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Preacher turns a page in the Bible. Gideon has his mo open like a fish trying to get air. The Choir continues t SING. The Preacher gets down on his knees and holds Gideo hand; he bows his head. The Choir stops singing. The Bess Smith recording of "Muddy Water" is coming from somewhere the house. The Preacher looks around. Suzie is more puzzl She goes to find where the music is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie knocks on the door. No one answers. She peeps in. N one is in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Preacher and the choir all have their hands on Gideon Suzie enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where that music is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior and Pat are helping Linda carry her baggage inside Sunny reluctantly follows. It is obvious that Linda has l Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, hush that noise and get in this house. Make haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my daddy; I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda, drag him in here. If you be nice, I will take you to Disneyland. Pat, Linda and Junior put the suitcases down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you don't have to say anything if you don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hear what happened. My brother is a jackass and a damn fool. The both of you have been as scarce as hen's teeth. Linda looks down, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda, take Sunny in the backyard. Take a bowl so you can pick some strawberries. Sunny will enjoy it. Rhonda and Sunny leave. Pat turns on Junior about talking about Babe Brother and Linda in front of Sunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't talk about the boy's father in front of him. This is family business and we have to pull together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether the boy hears it or not, the man is still a jackass. Everyone should have some mother wit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something just took control of him. He stays out all night and comes home with a pocket full of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably Harry, but I hate to mention his name, because every time we say something about him something bad happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda and Sunny are looking under a strawberry plant. Su has strawberry stains around his mouth and on his shirt. Rhonda is putting her strawberries in the bowl. After get a bowl full, they lay on the grass, eating strawberries w looking up at the clouds slowly drifting by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is driving along a country road while Harry, sitting in the front seat next to him, yawns. Harry is ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us walk awhile. I grow weary when I sit still too long. Babe Brother's car stops in an orchard-like area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother and Harry get out of the car. They walk on a path that takes them under low hanging tree limbs. It get darker as they go deeper into the orchard. Babe Brother f the going rough and loses his footing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me your arm lest you fall. Harry has to help him stay on his feet. Babe Brother find necessary to take Harry's arm. Babe Brother stops and Har walks a few more steps ahead and waits for Babe Brother. ahead sitting on a branch is a huge white owl camouflaged tree branches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could swear I heard my son call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably heard the wind stirring up those dead leaves over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard his voice as clear as day. I better get back. Maybe something is wrong. Babe Brother turns and starts hurrying back before Harry object. He walks slowly after Babe Brother who is doublin the distance between himself and Harry as he runs through orchard to his car. Harry stops and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, Linda and Junior are seated at the table. The suitca are in the middle of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told Babe Brother that if Harry sets foot in our house again, I'm taking Sunny and leaving. Just as I said that, here come Harry and his old resurrected friends, hobbling up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how you got that black eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was unintentional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother reminds me of the story of the man who wanted to be sizable. He wanted to be tall but what he was really short on was brains. There was a time when people had moon fever were treated with leeches. The phone rings and Junior goes to pick it up. Linda's an Pat's attention is focused on the phone. Junior hands the phone to Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that nut of yours. Linda hesitates but Pat takes the phone from Junior and p it in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?  (beat) No. Nothing happened to him. Sunny and Rhonda enter. Linda turns to look. Sunny's hand and face look bloody from eating strawberries. She puts t phone down and examines his dirty face. Pat brings Linda wet towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. BAKER, a well built black man in his late 40's, is ma a new fishing pole. He is very involved. Mrs. Baker is standing beside him with her arms folded. She stares at h Mr. Baker glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counting the gray hairs in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counting the what? What does that have to do with the price of butter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to make conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Skip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in his pigeon cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry he got those birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the man next door is near death. Mr. Baker doesn't answer. He pauses for a moment of thoug Mrs. Baker sees that she is not going to get a response f her husband. She picks up an eyelet and Mr. Baker looks a her as if to say, keep your hands off. She gets the messa and lays the eyelet back on the work bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have gotten rid of those chickens. You don't hear them crowing anymore... I kind of miss it now. Mr. Baker admires his pole. He looks very closely at the details of his work. Rodney comes in, polishing his horn. Mr. Baker's expressi changes as he watches Rodney out of the corner of his eye Mrs. Baker gives Rodney a motherly pat on the head. Rodne puts the trumpet to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blow that thing in here. You blow that thing when I'm at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a man lying on a bus bench with his belongings. spotted dog is standing guard next to the bench. The dog' reflection is caught in a puddle of water. The dog has circles and sixes painted over his body. Old John taps on the bench with his pipe. The man lying o the bench stirs and gives Old John a wave to indicate tha is alright. Old John slowly gets his cart moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother drives around the block past Junior's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is at the window, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't he just park his car and come in and apologize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother sits in his car with the windows up. Junior tries to talk to him but Babe Brother will not roll down windows. He just stares at Junior, who is getting angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll down the window and let me talk to you. Babe Brother only stares at him. Junior gets more violent starts to shake the car. Pat calls from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it Junior!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman is in a squatting position. Suzie and her aide ar holding the woman by the arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda is painting her fingernails. Sunny watches her. Sh looks around to see if any adult is watching. She tries t talk Sunny into letting her paint his nails. He refuses b she tries to pull his hand towards her. He fights his way free and stands up and kicks the bottle of nail polish ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, come see what Sunny did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is sitting in a chair; her head is bent forward. Gi is TALKING in his sleep. She awakes and nods off again. H sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as he keeps his throat clear, he is able to get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a fresh pot of coffee. Okra and I thought you need a rest. I'll stand guard. Okra wants to talk to you anyway. Harry helps Suzie to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okra is painfully standing on his bad feet. He is in his security-guard uniform, holding a bouquet of greens. As S comes in, Okra tries to stand upright at attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you these greens and some salt meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is very thoughtful of you. I haven't had time to tend to my garden like I should. Suzie takes the greens and puts them on the counter. She squeezes Okra's hand as a thank you. She pours him a cup coffee. Okra eases down into the chair. He crosses his le and starts massaging his feet. Suzie get herself a cup of coffee and sits opposite him. stretches and tries to hold back a yawn. Okra looks at he a slightly desirous way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Gideon and I are lodge brothers and it has always been a policy to take care of the wives if something happens to our brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very sweet, but Gideon has already taken care of everything in case something happens to him. He has a policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you become a widow, you will need someone around to fix the whatnots. We like for the widow to marry someone in the lodge. I know Gideon ain't gone yet, but there will be a lot of his old friends coming around to get in line. I just want you to consider this as a kind of a conditional proposal, to be first in line so to speak. Suzie keeps herself under control; she tries to find word say. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I have to go feed my dog. She turns the fire out from under the coffee pot and exit the back door. Okra unties his shoes and begins to massage his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is sitting by the bed, just visible through the win He seems restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is only one hen left in the coop. The garden is ful weeds. The sunflowers are bent by the force of the wind. bag is thrown over the fence. The shadows of pigeons flying overhead race along the gro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two shadows on the wall are facing each other. The shadow are the heads of two women, Suzie and Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Harry lied about how that boy Hocker got kilt. And it was Harry who saw Emory last before they found him hanging over a levee like someone would hang a hog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember Harry always trying to help someone. He got Lulla's daughter out of trouble. He was always running to the store for someone who couldn't leave the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry always shows his good side and, like the moon, the other side is black. Back home he always did try to act like the colored gentleman. I'm telling you Harry is nothing but evil. I'm warning you -- you can't keep a wild animal as a pet around children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry has a plate of food in his hand. He stands facing himself in the mirror, staring at himself while he eats. opens the door to leave but Sunny is in the hallway with back turned sweeping. Harry stares at him and decides to back in his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Okra asked me to marry him the other evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rush your mouth, girl. No, he didn't. He cannot be that big of a damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked Harry about it. He didn't own up to it. He said he didn't know what got into Okra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just raffish. Harry put him up to it. Before evening sun sets, I would have his belongings back on Route 55, that old fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't accuse him just dry long 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody who have been associated with Harry end up with pennies over their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What must I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was left up to me, I would poison him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sees that it is safe to leave. He sees Sunny sweepi in Gideon's room. Gideon is sound asleep. Sunny is sweepi around the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry comes in and Hattie and Suzie stop talking. Harry i aware that he was the subject. The SOUND of the boy next playing his horn is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon to you. Harry waits for Hattie to respond but it is obvious that Hattie isn't about to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to check on Gideon. Harry moves out of her way to let her go by. Hattie doesn even give him a glance. Harry continues to look at her as disappears into Gideon's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As God is my witness, I have never done anything to that woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have done something to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since she has repented, all she does is throw stones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie is a different person now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make no bones about where I'm going to spend eternity. I have always been wild and you know that. If you are made to feel half a man, what do you think the other half is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you brought that up as to who you are. I have to know who is in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You invited me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you are a good man, a friend. Are you a friend? Harry takes his time in looking for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that boy next door playing that his horn. If he was a friend, he would stop irritating people, but if he stops practicing, he wouldn't be perfect in what he does someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie enters Harry's room. She goes through his things. reads one of his letters. As she walks over to the window reading his letter, she steps on the plate, cracking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to leave. Harry looks sad and suddenly a lot older as if what she s has taken away some of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okra, M.C. and Herman want to go back home with me.  (beat) Suzie, I'm not a bad fellow; I just like to have a good time.  (beat) M.C. is coming by to pick me up tonight. I'll come back to get my things. Well, I hope Gideon recovers. You know I have an extra picture of one of my sons that I would like for you to put with those baby pictures over your dresser. It's better than being in my dusty wallet with addresses and names of people who are no longer on this earth. Suzie takes the picture. She seems as if she has doubts a having asked Harry to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say my so-longs to Gideon before I leave and I truly wish that he will get well. Suzie continues to look at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie is reading Harry's letters when he appears behind Hattie turns but is not surprised or concerned about Harr She hands him back his letters, looks at him for a moment goes. Harry looks down at the cracked dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. and Herman are packing. Okra is all dressed up with pair of Stacy Adams shoes that make his feet look exaggeratedly long. Babe Brother and Harry are sitting at table playing blackjack. Okra picks up one thing at a tim making the packing much harder. There is a stack of old d 78 record; Okra, trying to step over the records, kicks o a box of mothballs that roll across the floor. Okra has t step over boxes of toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you buy so much toilet paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got that on the job when I was a janitor. They didn't pay me. Harry picks up an old cigar box that falls opens. Dice, shotgun shells, some spent .38 slugs and an old rusty kni a crab apple switch, land on the floor. Harry picks up th knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose old piece of knife is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my brother's knife. Harry gives the knife to Babe Brother and signals him to it in his pocket. The SOUND of the thunder has an unreal violence to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would be a bad time for me to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra? (then back to Babe Brother) Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up. (beat) What would you give to be rich? Babe Brother humps his shoulder. Babe Brother looks at hi hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had Moms and Pops given me my share of what was mine, I could have been rich by now. Linda and I had it all worked out. Harry wins the first hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know your mind is on your wife but you should never treat a woman as an equal. You want to get your wife back, get another woman, one of those big hip women that will ride you till you sweat. Harry wins another hand. M.C. and Okra are still packing while Herman is eating Argo Starch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double the stakes? Babe Brother agrees but his thoughts are obviously somewh else. Harry studies his hand and looks at Babe Brother; h puts down his hand. Babe Brother wins and is quite please The next series of hands are won by Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C., you ever heard of a real man having one woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, lord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When one woman puts you out, you have another to take you in. You don't drive around without a spare tire, do you? The more mules you have hitched, the easier it is to plough. Harry loses another hand and Babe Brother suddenly has a of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman, let me borrow a few bucks. Herman stand over him with a roll of bills and peels off several.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you. Bless you. Herman is standing behind Babe Brother, SINGING to himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the ground there is a hole and green grass growing around the hole. Now in the hole there is tree and green grass growing all around the tree. Now there is a hole in the ground, a tree in the hole and green grass growing around the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me share something with you. Harry stops and thinks for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie is a snake. That woman broke up so many homes and caused a lot of misery and because she calls herself getting religion everything is put right. Okra is taking several shotguns out of the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These damn things are unloaded, ain't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important to know the difference between the incoming fire and the outgoing fire. As Amos and Andy might say, "We is the outgoing fire." Come with us, son. We'll show you some steaming hot juke joints, steaming hot women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pot full of chitlins and a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go by the house first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will wait for you as long as we can. I got to get my things from your mother's house. Babe Brother hurries out. M.C., Herman and Okra flop down chairs and on the bed and look at their watches. Harry sits at the table tapping out a rhythm on the table WHISTLING very softly to himself. Suddenly Harry sees tha Babe Brother left the pile of money on the table. A look concern comes over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining hard. Babe Brother gets out of the car. Run to get out of the rain, he slips and falls; he tries to g up but slips and falls again. He gets up and walks slowly the steps as if he doesn't care whether he gets wet or no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie helps him to take his wet coat off. She goes into t kitchen, puts his coat in front of the stove. The knife f out. She picks it up and looks at it like she would throw away but Babe Brother takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get my suitcase out of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back home with Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard some foolish things in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is coming to pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  (forcefully) You sit right there with your no manners self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is carrying a roll of roofing paper. Pat, Rhonda, Linda and Sunny run to the porch to get out of the rain. Junior stacks the roofing paper in the corner of the porc and stamps the mud off his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior, Pat, Linda and Rhonda come in to help Suzie move bed from under the rain dripping through the hole in the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunny stands in the doorway watching his father sharpen h knife that he got from Harry. Babe Brother is unaware tha his son is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Babe Brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother is in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you didn't ask Babe Brother to help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he was busy. He is mad 'cause he wanted to get in the garage to get his things so he could go with Harry. Linda has a surprised look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he is busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is preoccupied sharpening his knife with a sharpening stone. He is almost in a trance. Junior comes rather angrily. Sunny goes and sits in the shadows in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why in the hell didn't you help mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her I would if she would give me time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you if your master would have told you to fix the hole in the roof, you would have rebuilt the whole damn house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always got the best of it around here and when Dad always talks about my son, it is always you, so you fix the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a damn lie and you know it. Every time father asks you to do something, you either half-ass do it or run off and hide. Mama asked you to turn the dirt in her garden and you told her, with your smart ass self, that you weren't a farmer; get Junior to do it. Every time someone asks you to do something, you always say, tell Junior to do it. Boy, you ought to grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you about calling me boy. I ain't no boy. See, you and Dad got a bad habit of calling me boy. You call me boy in front of my wife. You think I'm going to fix the roof? I hope the wind blows the whole damn thing off and it pours down rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to break your damn neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunny is sitting in a chair listening to his father and u argue in the kitchen. A car outside passes and the lights from the car form a crochet-like moving pattern on the wa behind him. Sunny is only lit for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother starts gathering up his things to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving and don't even call me when the shoe falls 'cause all he did for me was to try and run my life. I'm tired of people saying Babe Brother this, Babe Brother that. What's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dumb ass, it's Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Sam. Samuel. Babe Brother attempts to get up but Junior pushes him dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down! Babe Brother hits Junior on the jaw, driving him backward causing the overhead lamp to sway violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, Pat and Linda hear the noise coming from the kitch and rush to see what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother and Junior are both reaching for the knife. Junior is on top of Babe Brother, who is stretched out on table trying to reach the knife. Junior grabs the knife f and Babe Brother flips over to defend himself. Babe Broth grabs Junior's wrist as Junior tries to push the knife against his throat. Suzie comes in and grabs part of the knife with her hand Junior's wrist with her other hand. Pat and Linda try to the two men apart while pleading with Junior. Blood drips from Suzie's hand to the table, forming a poo under Babe Brother's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it! Look what you are doing! Babe Brother's eyes are rolled to the back. Junior's eyes huge; he has an animal look on his face. The SOUND of struggling people breathing heavily is amplified. The poo blood on the table grows larger. Junior slowly becomes aware of the blood and his body relaxes. He calmly releases the knife. Junior takes his mother's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone get some lard out of the ice box. Pat attempts to get the lard but pain in her stomach forc her to sit down. Linda gets the lard out and hands it to Junior. Babe Brother raises himself. The blood from Suzie dripping from his head. Rhonda is trying to hold Sunny ba Junior holds his mother's hand under the faucet. It is a cut. The bleeding won't stop. Pat is sitting at the blood-stained table unable to move. is PANTING, sweating, and holding her stomach. Linda is caught between trying to help Suzie and attending to Pat. Babe Brother helps to make a wad of cloth to press in her hand to Stop the bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to need some stitches. We better take her to the emergency hospital. Babe Brother is shamefully calm now and very humble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive her to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will take her. You all stay here and watch Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Pat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay now. Suzie attempts to go see Gideon but Babe Brother and Juni turn her to the door. Going through the kitchen door, Jun intentionally turns his back to Babe Brother. Babe Brothe stares at Junior's back as he walks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The automatic doors open and Junior, Babe Brother and Suz enter. There is a long line of people waiting at the registration window as well as groups of people filling o forms. Other patients are seated and waiting patiently to the doctor. Suzie finally gets to the registration window. A NURSE, white, 25, with extremely long fingernails that curve bac around, is surprisingly sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of emergency are you here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take a look at it. Suzie puts her hand through the window. The Nurse stands to get a better look. The Nurse takes the wad out of her hand. The bleeding has stopped. The Nurse takes a deep breath. The Nurse glances up to no the blood stains on the back of Babe Brother head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bleeding has stopped but it will need stitches. You will have to fill out this form. How will this be covered, insurance, cash or check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. It will be paid. Just let her see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have Medicare. The Nurse hands Suzie a form, but Babe Brother takes the form. The Nurse looks again at Babe Brother's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need to see the doctor too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just my mother. Babe Brother fills out the form with Suzie's help and han the form back to the Nurse. They find a seat all together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room slowly fills with people and Babe Brother and Ju offer their seats to those there for medical care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Police Officers bring in a man handcuffed to a bed. T woman officer carries a shotgun. The male police officer carries a clip board. The Prisoner is obviously in no condition to escape or cause trouble. They are allowed to directly to the emergency room without waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More injured people come but in spite of their condition are told that they have to wait. There is only standing r Junior and Babe Brother are standing next to the wall. On the other side of the room, Suzie is looking quietly a them as if she is in deep thought. Junior walks over to the reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it so crowded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it is Friday night and a full moon. Junior whispers to Babe Brother. They both start to laugh Suzie looks up and finds them in a fit of laughter. A fai smile appears on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is slowly getting up. He looks around. He calls fo Suzie. He slowly gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie, I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks by Linda, Pat, Rhonda, and Sunny, who are sleepi in chairs, on the floor and on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon opens the refrigerator and starts taking out bowls food and placing them on the table. He puts on a pot of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is busy eating almost everything in sight. A group mystified and sleepy faces appear at the door. Pat, Linda Rhonda and Sunny are all looking rather dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is wet from the night's rain. The garden looks more like a graveyard. Moisture drips from the sunflowers Gideon's nervous looking rooster jumps the fence and star to CROW. Skip is out early throwing rocks at his birds. The rocks on Gideon's roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother and Junior help Suzie out of the car. She ha her left hand bandaged. They are extremely exhausted. The walk up the porch to find Harry holding the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe what I heard took place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On seeing Suzie, Sunny jumps up, knocking the can of marb over the kitchen floor. He runs to give Suzie a hug. Sunn wants to touch her bandaged hand, but Linda stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Gideon doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is asleep now, but he was up all night eating. As Suzie goes to Gideon's room, she comes face to face wi Harry. She doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to pick up my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is SNORING loudly. On the night-stand is a plate w food left on it. Suzie feels his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sadly gets up. He looks at Babe Brother. Linda step front of Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to go see how your father is doing and then wash that blood off you and change shirts. Babe Brother is surrounded by Linda and Sunny who has his eyes fixed on Harry. They move as one heading for the bedroom. Harry seems a lot older. He sadly walks towards the kitch with his coffee cup. LOW ANGLE SHOT: Harry is slowly walking towards the MARBL that are scattered over the kitchen floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, Linda, Junior, Rhonda, Babe Brother, Sunny and Suzie all standing around waiting for Gideon to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon. Gideon's only response is to SNORE louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is Harry going to hang around? Babe Brother is in a corner all by himself. He looks down when Pat asks the question about Harry. A loud CRASHING SOUND comes from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is trying to raise himself from the floor. He pause for a moment and then collapses. Harry is in a lot of pai Harry's body contorts and then remains still. Babe Brother, Junior, Pat, and Linda, Suzie run in. Suzie tries to see if he is alive. Babe Brother tries to give h mouth to mouth resuscitation but Linda pulls him away. Ju tries to push down on Harry's chest. Babe Brother stares down at Harry and then goes slowly ba into the living room. Pat is on the phone dialing the paramedics. Everyone stands around Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two PARAMEDICS work on Harry. One of the paramedics is a young Asian. The other is white with red hair. They liste for a heart beat and shake their heads in a negative mann They pack up their medical case. The Asian's accent is ve difficult to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing we can do for him. The Paramedics start to leave without the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, aren't you going to take him with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had died in our care, we would be required to take him. Since we found him dead, you will have to wait for the county to pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will that take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would depend on how busy it is. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is stretched out on the floor. A blanket covers everything except his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie, Marsh, Okra, Herman, and M.C. all come in. Marsh looks cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slipped on some marbles that were on the floor. Then his heart gave out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sunny) I told you to always put those marbles up and not to leave them just anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor thing is not to blame. Rhonda, take Sunny for a walk. Marsh hands Rhonda several dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, go around to the store and buy what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would anybody object if I take a look at him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Harry would like it. Hattie goes over and pulls the blanket back. Okra, M.C. a Herman hurry over to take a quick glance. They huddle beh Hattie, peeping over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never noticed how big his eyes were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda is helping Babe Brother wash Suzie's blood out of h hair. She dries his hair with a towel. Sonny hands Babe Brother a clean shirt, Gideon's shirt. He puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon is sitting on the edge of his bed looking through scraps of leftovers on his plate. He puts his pants on. A moves about, his joints SNAP and POP. He picks up the emp plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother is on the phone with the county morgue. He g into an argument with the people on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister... Mister... Excuse me for cutting you off but we pay taxes too. We should not have to pay you to take a 24-hour lunch break. Babe Brother hands the phone to Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coroner said that he was out here, and knocked on the door and no one was here. Junior steps over the body, holding a pot of coffee in hi hand. The Preacher is sitting with Suzie talking in a low voice Pat, Rhonda and Sunny come in with boxes of chicken snack Linda hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know when he will be out this way again. Somebody downtown is going to hear about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just do that in the colored neighborhood. If he had been white, they would had him on his feet and out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got white meat and I got dark meat. I know it sounds cruel but we have to eat. Gideon comes in walking very slowly, holding his plate ou Everyone is shocked. Gideon is completely unaware of the period that he has been sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are you having another party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better come sit down. You are still sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gal, you're talking to John Henry. When was I sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been out for almost three weeks. The Preacher gives him a pat on the back and shakes Gideo hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had long conversations with the Lord about you. Didn't we, Sister Suzie? I said we need him down here, Lord. Gideon smiles in appreciation. He pushes his plate out to Pat, indicating that he wants it filled with chicken. Gid is about to bite into the chicken when he notices Harry's feet sticking out. He points with the chicken in his hand has a mystified look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our friend Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not our Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it wasn't. Gideon seems to weaken for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dropped dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie, you can be so mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has he been dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut it on an old rusty knife. Gideon is deeply concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you put on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's healing now. Gideon looks over at his two sons as if to ask them about

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you will take care of your mother better than that when I'm gone. Junior and Babe Brother both have their heads down. Linda Sunny move closer to Babe Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Brother, is that my shirt that you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not wearing my shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're too big. Gideon stares at Babe Brother and then looks around towar Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is the undertaker coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't say. I'll try calling them again. Hattie moves closer to Herman and speaks so only he can h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't M.C. and you drag him to your house? Herman moves away with a look of disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry didn't have any relatives living, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry was in the world by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody has to take responsibility for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you look through his things to see if you can find a number? Okra, Marsh, Hattie, Herman, and M.C. go to Harry's room, leaving Suzie and Gideon sitting opposite each other with door to the kitchen separating them. Junior, the Preacher Pat are eating chicken. Linda is on the phone trying to g through to the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that? They hung up in my face. I'll fix them. I'll show them just how mean I can get. She rapidly dials the number. There is a BUSY SIGNAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M.C. and Marsh are going through Harry's boxes. They take old blues records, books, a big Bible, and books on Dunba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are letters to his son. Hattie reads the letters in a corner by herself. She stop reading for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't know if I was right about Harry. She seems frustrated with herself not being able to come terms about who was Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of people are standing around looking at Gideon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Preacher is sleep in his chair, SNORING loudly. Babe Brother and Linda are sitting together, talking in almost whisper. Sunny is asleep in his lap. Babe Brother is find it difficult to apologize for his recent behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have more sense than to give up everything, my family, you and Sunny. It wasn't me, I mean the real me inside my body. I'm glad it's over. It's like a veil has been lifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a veil has been lifted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like I've been swimming in muddy waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like muddy waters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like all those things old country people try to tell you what hell is like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe the things I was doing. It was like an internal struggle going on inside my body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nip and tuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what lesson have we learned from all of this, Babe Br... Sam... I mean Samuel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it proves you really care about me. You hung in there. Linda looks at Babe Brother for a length of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you boys going to fix that roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as I rest a bit.  (beat) I meant as soon as we are back to normal again, anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am thinking about myself when poor Harry is resting on the floor of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry's body lies there motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Preacher is SNORING violently. Babe Brother is asleep on the floor. Sunny is asleep sitt on Linda's lap. Linda's feet rest on Babe Brother's chest Junior and Pat are looking at the baby pictures. Pat is holding her hand across her stomach feeling the baby kick Rhonda is asleep in a chair. Suzie and Gideon are sitting at the dining room table. Su is cutting the dead leaves off of a small potted plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels like a storm has passed... Hattie read some of Harry's letters to a woman he had a child by. The child had died and he was writing to give her some comfort. Hattie didn't know that deep down at the bottom of Harry's hate, there was some love. The SOUND of Rodney's trumpet is heard but is no longer irritating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you the story about the man who wanted to make his own mind up about heaven and hell? He didn't want nobody's opinion but his own. Suzie doesn't pay any attention; she is involved with her potted plant. Gideon looks over at the Preacher, who is s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to check out heaven first. He gets a round trip ticket to heaven. He gets in heaven and finds it just like back home. People dripping with sweat, working in the fields, hardly surviving. He asked a man who was getting a drink of water, "I thought the streets were paved with gold." "They are but you won't see them," he said. "Boy, you got to work day and night cause idleness is sinfulness." So he takes the other half of his ticket and takes the express to hell. He sees people stretched out on their backs kicking back, picking their teeth. "Man, this is a dream." He asked, "What's you'll doing?" They all hollered back, "Sinning." The devil was shaking hands with everyone and came up to him and said, "Please to meet you." He asked, "I thought you'll was supposed to be burning in fire." Someone said, "Man, ain't no fire down here except under that pot of chitlins." The man was going go ask the preacher back on earth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear any joke about colored people being in hell. You're being irreverent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm almost finished. I'm about to come to the punch line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear any tales about colored people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these are white people, anybody. The punch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care to hear any jokes about people being in hell. This cut on my hand reminds me that it is nothing to laugh at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a tale. The RATTLING of pots and dishes starts suddenly. Harry's starts to sway gently as if he were about to get up. Everyone is frozen. Babe Brother and Linda remain asleep. rocking caused by the earthquake doesn't wake them. M.C., Herman, Okra and Hattie and Marsh enters the dining room. Harry's feet are seen in the kitchen still swaying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that an earthquake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's something. Babe Brother wakes in a sweat and sits next to Linda like child needing protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cold. I need to get out into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, noontime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how they going to bury this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plant him in Potter's Field. He doesn't need a marked grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie, your true colors are unbearable. You got some mean ways. Don't worry about the boy getting a burial. He still has some friends left on this earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His winter has come and gone and I know right now he is answering for a lot of things. M.C., Okra and Herman move away from Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my job to pray for his soul and I would like to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda is sitting next to Sunny on the front porch. She h an angry expression. Sunny is trying to please her by offering her his airplane. He pushes the airplane near her and she pushes it back wi violent shove. He persists in offering her his airplane. A crowd of people is still standing around in front of Gideon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy, you still got that dead man in your house. Sunny and Rhonda don't respond. A middle-aged woman, VIRGINIA, one of Gideon's neighbors, passes Sunny and Rho knocks on the screen door and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you all haven't had a chance to cook or do anything with that dead man in your kitchen. You must be starved to death. Some of your neighbors have got together and we set up a picnic table in my backyard with food and everything to feed all you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virginia, that is so wonderful of you all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the dead wagon comes, we ought to leave a note telling them we'll be down the street at a picnic. Gideon comes back in with Suzie, who is helping tie his t They all line up and file out the front door with Suzie a Gideon leading the way. Pat is holding her stomach with a thoughtful look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we better be ready. Junior looks concerned as he follows Pat out the door. Su follows Rhonda, who is still mad at him. Babe Brother and Linda are the last ones out. Babe Brother takes a long lo in the direction of Harry as Linda pulls him out. She sla the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry's body lies on the floor. On the kitchen sink are Suzie's jars of cuttings, which have developed a maze of roots.
